JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national living in PERSON ( GPE ) . He was represented by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Ambassador PERSON , Head of ORG at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant was , at the relevant time , the owner of ORG , a company producing starch from corn and sugar . Due to ongoing ecological problems with effluents emitted by his company , he installed an in - house sewerage plant .
On DATE ORG granted an operating permit .
On DATE it requested the applicant to comment on charges concerning non - compliance with environmental regulations as set out in the operating permit .

On DATE the applicant filed his comments . He submitted that the reason for temporarily exceeding environmental limits was the fact that the sewerage system was still in its early stages . As proof he requested that GPE , LOC ( PERSON ) , PERSON , a Member of ORG ( PERSON ) , and PERSON , the head of ORG ) as well as GPE and GPE be summoned .

On DATE ORG convicted the applicant under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW Gewerbeordnung ) and issued a fine in the amount of CARDINAL , CARDINAL NORP schillings ( ORG ) . It found him guilty of having repeatedly and continuously overstretched the capacity of the sewerage plant at issue , by exceeding the maximum admissible amount of inflow as set out in the operating permit .
On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal .

Having held an oral hearing in which it had heard K. and S. , CARDINAL experts , ORG ( PERSON ) , on DATE , discontinued proceedings . It found that the pollution was due to technical problems which were outside the applicant 's sphere .
On DATE the ORG Governor lodged a complaint with ORG ) . The applicant did not comment on the Governor 's appeal .

By a decision of DATE ORG quashed the decision and remitted the case to the ORG . It found that the significant breach of the inflow limits constituted sufficient reason to believe that the actual deviation from the operating licence 's limits was apt to constitute an environmental risk which the regulations under LAW aimed to keep to a minimum . This was tantamount to an unlawful change to the operation of the plant . Following ORG decision the applicant did not lodge another request for taking of evidence .

Thereupon the ORG , on DATE , partially allowed the applicant 's appeal . While , following the legal opinion of ORG , it upheld the applicant 's conviction by ORG , it reduced the fine imposed on the applicant to CARDINAL ( ORG ) ( ORG CARDINAL ) . As a reason for this reduction the ORG , referring explicitly to LAW , found that the proceedings had lasted an unreasonably long time .
On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG .
By a decision of DATE ORG refused to deal with the case for lack of prospect of success and , upon the applicant 's request , remitted the case to ORG .
On DATE the latter dismissed the applicant 's complaint , the judgment being served on the applicant 's counsel on DATE .
Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW , in so far as relevant , reads as follows :
“ The following constitutes an administrative criminal offence , subject to a maximum fine of ORG CARDINAL :
( CARDINAL ) Any change to an existing operation of a plant for which an operating permit had been granted or operation thereof . ”
